financial literacy earning in this lesson, you will learn about earning: making money from a job or public benefits programs. start! start! start!

earning what youll learn you will be able to: name 2 sources of income read and complete a paycheck and paystub define taxes know when and where to go for free tax preparation name 1 benefit of a checking account describe how to deposit a check 35 minutes: learn about earning money. go! go! go!
when youre finished %tap% next
what is earning? earning money is when you receive money from working at a job or from public benefits. 01 earning %tap% next
what is income? earning the money you take home is called your income. your income can change every month and come from many sources. 02 %tap% next

how do you get income? earning you may receive your income in different ways (not just cash): 03 direct depositmoney is transferred into your bank account from your employer. work earnings checkmoney is promised through an official paper note that can be deposited in a bank. work earnings & ssi debit cardmoney is given on a card that can be used to make purchases. snap & wic %tap% next

income is money you take home. there are many sources of income you may have. you may be paid in cash, by check or receive money on a government-issued card such as wic, snap, or tanf. lottery tickets, coupons and credit cards are not sources of income. earning summary go! go! go!

you need to answer the question before you can continue oops ok ok ok ok ok ok thats ok! lets learn a little more about banks. you dont have an account learn more learn more learn more learn more learn more learn more great! you already have an account. would you like to learn more about banks or skip to the next section? you have an account! learn more learn more learn more learn more learn more learn more skip skip skip skip skip skip do you have a bank account? banking yes, i have a bank account. yes, i have a bank account. yes, i have a bank account. yes, i have a bank account. yes, i have a bank account. yes, i have a bank account. no, i do not have a bank account. no, i do not have a bank account. no, i do not have a bank account. no, i do not have a bank account. no, i do not have a bank account. no, i do not have a bank account. earning go! go! go!

the bank lets you trade in your checks for cash without charging a fee. cashing a check is free putting money in your account helps you not spend money unwisely. banks help you save money the bank keeps your money protected from fires and theft. banks keep your money safe a bank is a financial institution that holds and lends money. what is a bank? earning

credit unions are non-profit financial groups where members own the institution and make decisions based on members needs and desires. what is a credit union? earning you may need to live in a certain area or work a certain job to join. you need to be a member credit unions offer more personal care and attention than bigger banks. locally owned credit unions sometimes provide better benefits than banks. credit unions are like banks

people usually have 2 accounts in a bank or credit union: bank accounts earning savings account an account at a bank or credit union that earns interest and is not accessed frequently. checking account an account at a bank or credit union that is active money is deposited and withdrawn regularly.
checking account your checking account is active! checking account earning this is the account your paycheck is deposited into and where you pay your bills (rent, electricity, water)
checking account this account is linked to your debit card and checkbook. checking account earning you can withdraw money easily.

savings account checking account you can transfer money to and from your savings account. bank accounts earning warning! if you transfer too often your bank may charge fees. set up a monthly transfer between your accounts to accumulate savings!
savings account this account is for money that you save for future purchases or emergencies. savings account earning save money here for a car, home or education

when you earn money at work, some money is taken out of your original pay. these are called deductions. they are legal and required. deductions earning for some jobs (usually full-time), you can choose to have money taken out of your paycheck for benefits such as health care, dental care, or help with transportation. you and your employer share the cost. employer benefits the government takes money out of your paycheck to pay for services that benefit everyone, like roads, buses, schools, and the refugee resettlement program. taxes

earning how much will she earn? fatima earns $720.00 every two weeks, but the hotel takes $163.00 out of her check to pay taxes to the government. $720.00 - $163.00 = $557.00 fatima also gets health insurance from her employer, which is another $45.00 each pay period. $557.00 $45.00 = $512.00 so fatima receives a paycheck of $512.00 after paying taxes and benefits.
earning paystubs in addition to receiving a paycheck, you will also get a paystub which explains deductions taken from your pay and how your paycheck amount was calculated.
paystubs hourly rate your hourly rate is how much money you make for each hour you work. in this example, the hourly rate is $12.25. earning
paystubs taxes on your paystub, you will see the amount of money you pay in taxes for different government programs like medicare and social security. earning

paystubs totals net pay is the amount of money you earned after taxes on your paycheck. this is how much money you take home. you can see the total amount of money you made all year by looking for the year to date amount. earning
paystubs paycheck your net pay will be the total amount of your paycheck. earning

ok ok ok ok ok ok you need to answer the question before you can continue oops now lets take a closer look at taxes. do you know how the government uses your taxes? taxes yes, i know. yes, i know. yes, i know. yes, i know. yes, i know. yes, i know. no, i dont know. no, i dont know. no, i dont know. no, i dont know. no, i dont know. no, i dont know. earning go! go! go!

many organizations can assist you with filing taxes. some are good and honest; others are dishonest and trying to make money off of you. tax preparation earning good tax preparation services the organization is recommended by a caseworker or by your bank. the organization is a non-profit (they do not earn money) they do not charge money for service. if you get a tax refund, they do not expect a portion of it. bad tax preparation services they advertise heavily the organization is a big business that makes money they require a fee, or expect you to give them part of your refund they promise that you will get a lot of money back.

taxes are legally taken out of your paycheck and go to the governmentso that they can provide certain things for people. what are taxes for? earning transportation and infrastructurebuses and roads schoolspublic schools and universities public benefitssocial security and medicare

when you submit your tax information before april 15, you include: filing taxes earning discount on your taxes for children or families with low to moderate income. deductions information on how many people are sharing your income. family size summarizes how much money you made and paid in tax during the year. this is provided by your employer. w2 forms %tap% the w2 form to zoom in

you can get free tax preparation assistance by visiting the irs website: volunteer income tax assistance free tax preparation earning vita sites are generally located at community and neighborhood centers, libraries, schools, shopping malls and other convenient locations across the country. to locate the nearest vita site near you, call 800-906-9887. where to find vita the volunteer income tax assistance (vita) program offers free tax help to people who generally make $56,000 or less, persons with disabilities and limited english speaking taxpayers who need assistance in preparing their own tax returns. irs-certified volunteers provide free basic income tax return preparation with electronic filing to qualified individuals. volunteer income tax assistance (vita)

you can also deposit a check by other methods: check deposit methods earning the employer transfers money from their account to your account on payday. there is no paper check you will only receive your paystub as a receipt. direct deposit take the check to an atm instead of a bank. the atm must belong to your bank and offer check deposit. atm deposit some banks allow you to deposit a check by taking a picture of it. the check is deposited automatically and funds are available in 1-2 days. mobile deposit

what is earning? earning direct deposit earning restaurant bank account gebres bank account - $373.19 + $373.19 with direct deposit, there is only 1 step. $373.19 immediately goes from the restaurants bank account to gebres account on payday. you can ask your employer about direct deposit and fill out paperwork to set it up.

you can get help filing your taxes you must file your taxes before april 15th and can get free tax preparation by visiting the irs website. earning go! go! go! taxes pay for public benefits earning go! go! go! taxes are legally collected by the government to pay for things like transportation and infrastructure, schools and public benefits. put money in the bank to earn interest you can deposit money into your checking or savings account in a bank or credit union and earn interest on your money. earning go! go! go! what did we learn about earning? you can receive income in cash, by check, on a debit card or through direct deposit. there are many ways to receive income such as a paycheck from your employer and public benefits like wic, snap, ssi and tanf. earning go! go! go!

what would you do? if you had 1,000 dollars right now, what would you spend it on? why would you spend the money that way? how did you make that decision? spending ?

something you desire or enjoy, but not something you need to survive. wants something that is required for survival - you cannot live without it. needs knowing the difference between wants and needs will help you spend money wisely. wants vs. needs you will have to make daily choices about how you spend your money. needs vs. wants spending need want

what is a budget? spending a budget is a way to track money coming in and out of your household. keep track of your income and spending as it can change each month. if your expenses are lower than your income, you will be able to save money. keep expenses lower than income complete and update your budget once a month to keep track of your spending. budget often always plan to include money in your budget for savings whenever possible. budget to save

budgeting ernesto and maria are planning their family budget. lets look at their income and expenses for 3 months and see how they spend money. can you see the differences between the monthly budgets? spending start! start! start!
february budget spending ernesto and maria made a family budget to track their income and expenses. they arent saving money because their expenses are more than their income!

february budget spending ernesto and maria are earning $1,605 per month but are spending $1,850. they are spending $245.00 more than they are earning. lets find out what they can do to reduce their expenses so they can save money! go! go! go!

oops ok ok ok ok ok ok you must view all of the ways to reduce expenses before continuing. reduce expenses spending %tap% each of the pictures to find out what you can do to reduce expenses: go! go! go!

electricity/gas spending ways to reduce household expenses with electricity and gas: turn off the lights before you leavethe house unplug appliances when not in use turn the heat down use a fan in the summer unless it is really hot then use the ac close

transportation spending ways to reduce household expenses with transportation: compare public transportation options a monthly bus or train pass may be cheaper than day passes walk or bike as much as possible close

food spending ways to reduce household expenses with food: compare product prices and find the cheapest grocery store near you buy things that are off-brand or on sale buy items in bulk avoid convenience stores (small stores) which are usually more expensive buy less junk food look for coupons and use a bonus card for discounts close

electronics spending ways to reduce household expenses with electronics: wait to buy children phones until they are old enough and will be responsible research cell phone plans to find thebest deal for your familys needs cut the cost for cable and sign up for discounted internet and use computer reduce time spent using technology close
clothing spending ways to reduce household expenses with clothing: look for thrift stores or donationresources ask your caseworker if they have clothing donations close

you may find other ways to spend money in your daily lives. some of these services are offered through a phone app, and others are available online or in-person. select each image to view more information about each way to spend money. other ways to spend spending go! go! go!

money orders spending these are similar to checks, but are guaranteed by a bank or post office. you usually pay a fee to purchase a money order. some rental companies require money orders for rent payments. if you lose a money order, its like losing cash.
venmo spending venmo is a phone application that allows friends and family to send and receive money between their bank accounts.

money orders spending a common service to wire (send) money from one person to another. western union has many in-person branch locations. this is common for sending money to people in other countries. you can also send money around the world with the western union multi-language app.
paypal spending this service is available on smartphones or computers. it allows you to make and receive payments through your paypal account, which is connected to your bank account.

people usually have 2 accounts in a bank or credit union: bank accounts saving & protecting savings account an account at a bank or credit union that earns interest and is not accessed frequently. checking account an account at a bank or credit union that is active money is deposited and withdrawn regularly.
checking account your checking account is active! checking account saving & protecting this is the account your paycheck is deposited into and where you pay your bills (rent, electricity, water)
checking account this account is linked to your debit card and checkbook. checking account saving & protecting you can withdraw money easily.

savings account checking account you can transfer money to and from your savings account. bank accounts saving & protecting warning! if you transfer too often your bank may charge fees. set up a monthly transfer between your accounts to accumulate savings!
savings account this account is for money that you save for future purchases or emergencies. savings account saving & protecting save money here for a car, home or education go! go! go!

savings & interest saving & protecting money in your savings account earns interest. for a loan, you borrow money and you pay interest. when you save, the bank pays you interest. savings accounts are meant to be used less frequently and protect your money while it slowly earns interest. low risk way to save money most bank accounts have a savings account attached to the checking account. checking & savings the bank gives you interest and protects your money. the interest is small less than 1% each year. benefits of saving in a bank

stocks, bonds, cds saving & protecting there are a variety of stocks, bonds, and cds where you can invest your money to earn returns. some of these accounts are risky: research these options carefully before you invest. back back back retirement fund saving & protecting retirement funds are low-cost options to save money. you might have heard the terms 403(b), or a roth ira. these are all retirement funds. they are designed to be accessed once you retire, often after age 65. back back back college fund saving & protecting college funds provided by some banks to save money for future education costs. this fund is meant to be accessed only for higher education and accrues more interest than a savings account. back back back other ways to save saving & protecting there are many account types that can save and earn money in the long-run. %tap% on the icons below to learn more about each. go! go! go!
what is fraud? saving & protecting fraud is when people try to trick you to steal your money. even if you are careful with your money, there are still many ways to experience fraud

atm safety saving & protecting back back back back back back do not write down your pin or keep it in your wallet. do not share your pin with anyone. at the atm, check behind you to make sure no one is looking over your shoulder or waiting. cover your hand when you enter your pin, at the store or at the atm. dont take out large amounts of cash, because if it gets stolen, you cant replace it. mail saving & protecting back back back back back back you probably receive a lot of mail, some of it is important but some of it is junk mail - make sure you read mail that comes directly from your bank. always track the money in your accounts by looking at your statements. if you see a purchase you do not recognize, alert your bank. sharing your information saving & protecting back back back banks and government will never call you about your money or ask for financial information over the phone. have the number for your bank in your phone. when in doubt, call the bank with the number that you are familiar with. before sharing your financial information, ask: why do you need this information? is it necessary? sometimes, giving your social security number is optional. never carry your social security number in your wallet or bag. prizes & gimmicks: saving & protecting back back back back back back be cautious and skeptical if someone says you won a prize. if it sounds too good to be true, it is probably a trick! you may receive letters, phone calls, or texts. how to prevent fraud saving & protecting %tap% on each image below to view strategies to protect your money. go! go! go!

tracking money saving & protecting it is important to always be aware of what money is deposited and withdrawn from your accounts and check for suspicious activity. go! go! go! you can track your money through an app provided by your bank. some banks offer mobile check deposit, where you can take a photo of a check to make a deposit. mobile banking if you have access to a computer and email, you can view statements, track your money and accounts, and move money between your accounts online. online banking you can receive bank statements in the mail that list all bank activity in the past month. check these statements to ensure everything is correct. printed bank statements

goal setting saving & protecting congratulations! you are almost at the end of this financial literacy course. weve learned a lot about the importance of savings, but now lets set some goals so you have a concrete plan for your future. what do you want to do with your savings?

setting a goal saving & protecting a goal is a clear plan that is achievable and solid. goals help guide your daily actions and how you manage your money. you cannot achieve a goal in a single day. achieving goals requires time, patience, and careful planning. plan it out just like you need to walk up a flight of stairs step by step, goals need to be accomplished in a series of small steps. step-by-step goals can be financial, like saving a certain amount of money; material, like buying a car; or experiential, like taking a college class. types of goals

components of a goal saving & protecting goals should have 4 components. %tap% each word to learn more: go! go! go! what why when how be specific and concrete in writing your goal. the clearer you write your goal, the better you will be able to identify how to achieve it! ask yourself what is your motivation why is it important to you? are you willing to make sacrifices to achieve your goal? set a specific deadline and check-ins along the way. goals can be short-term, mid-term, or long-term. outline specific strategies and tactics. identify your resources and where you may need help. click here to skip the drag and drop activity on the next slide when youre finished on this slide

terms.term: The interest rate on a credit card, calculated annually.
A computer that does some of the same functions and tasks as a bank employee. You can access your account from an ATM to withdraw cash, deposit checks, or see your account balance.
The place where a financial institution protects and maintains the money of an individual or company.
A record of all the money, with specific amounts, that came into and left your bank account. Bank statements usually record 1 month of activity.
Services provided through an employer, such as health insurance or retirement savings. You and the employer share the costs and money is taken out of your paycheck.
Taking and spending someones money (from a bank or company) and returning it later. When you borrow money, you need to pay interest.
A monthly financial plan for your household that specifies income and expenses.
A physical form of money; in the USA, the currency is dollars and cents, in bills and coins.

An official paper note that promises money from one person/business to another. Employers give employees checks for work, but checks are also used between individuals. Checks are replaceable and therefore safer than cash.
An account in a financial institution that is active money is deposited and withdrawn regularly. Checks and debit cards are linked to a Checking Account.
A card given by a bank or business that lets you buy items with borrowed money. You pay back the credit card company each month.
A number given to a person that represents their trustworthiness with borrowed money. Credit scores affect loans, mortgages, and ability to rent apartments or get jobs.
A card linked to your checking account. You can use your debit card to withdraw money at the ATM or make purchases.
Money that is owed to someone.
Money that is legally kept out of a paycheck that goes to taxes or benefits.
An amount of money placed in a bank account.
Making or obtaining money.
A percent of money that the bank pays you as a reward for keeping money in a savings account. This interest is usually small.
A trick or scam used by people to access your information and money.
A specific, achievable plan to accomplish something you want in the future.
All money coming into your household, from work earnings, public benefits, or other sources.
A percent that is paid back when you borrow money - like a service fee for borrowing. Interest is also the percent of money you earn with a savings account.
The amount of money that is borrowed and expected to be paid back.
A phone app run by your bank that allows you to do some banking tasks without visiting an actual bank location.
A website offered by your bank that allows you do some banking tasks online without visiting your bank. Similar to mobile banking.
A method of payment from an employer. Paychecks usually come in set intervals of time, such as every 2 weeks.
The receipt of the paycheck, with more details about work earnings, taxes, and benefits.
A four-digit number that you need in order to use your debit card. This number should be secret.
Making sure that your money is secure, safe, and protected from theft or fraud.
Putting away money, even in small amounts, in order to spend it later. Savings can be used in case of an emergency or unexpected expense, or to make an important life purchase.
An account in a financial institution that earns interest and is not accessed frequently.
All money leaving your household.
The part of your income that goes to the government, to provide beneficial services such as roads or schools.
Taking cash out of your account, usually at an ATM or a bank.
